IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Our mission is to catalyze communities, government, and other institutions to dismantle structural racial inequity and create equitable outcomes for all.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Our mission is to catalyze communities, government, and other institutions to dismantle structural racial inequity and create equitable outcomes for all.
IRS990.Desc: Center for Social Inclusion (CSI) catalyzes community, government, and other institutions to dismantle structural racial inequity and create equitable outcomes for all. Our strategic approach centers on four interlocking strategies: (1) working with community groups and national organizations to develop policy ideas, (2) capacity building through multi-racial coalition building, convenings, leadership development, and trainings, (3) developing tools for communicating about race, and (4) developing and implementing institutional change strategies to operationalize structural racial equity. This past year, CSI began significant work in partnership with the Haas Institute for a Fair and Inclusive Society. The Government Alliance on Race and Equity (GARE) is a project of CSI and leads all work with government, building and sharing effective approaches for building the capacity of local and regional government jurisdictions to advance equity and eliminate institutional and structural racism. Our main program areas and some key 2015 accomplishments are:Government Alliance on Race and Equity (GARE): The Government Alliance on Race and Equity (GARE) is a national network of government working to achieve racial equity and advance opportunities for all. GARE became a core program of CSIs. GARE had previously been associated with the Haas Institute for a Fair and Inclusive Society at University of California, Berkeley, using the Center for Ethical Leadership as a fiscal sponsor. Because of the shared alignment in a structural racism analysis, the move to CSI was ideal. GARE uses a three-prong approach:1)GARE is a membership organization that supports national and regional networks of jurisdictions that are at the forefront of work to achieve racial equity. (Currently, we have 18 cities and counties that are members.)2)GARE offers pathways for new jurisdictions to begin doing racial equity work, including year long learning curricula. (We began intense organizing in California and Minnesota to prepare to launch three year-long learning cohorts.)3)We support and build local and regional collaborations that are broadly inclusive and focused on achieving racial equity, including the provision of tools and resources that work to advance racial equity and create effective and inclusive democracies. (We released a Resource Guide, Racial Equity Tool, and issue papers on public sector jobs and contracting equity.) Energy Democracy: CSI co-convened and co-anchored the formation of the New York Energy Democracy Alliance in New York, a collaborative effort among 15 grassroots and community-based organizations across the state seeking racial and economic equity within the State of New Yorks Reforming the Energy Vision proceedings. Through this work, we have supported community-led policy demands around state energy plans and infrastructure development, and pushed for the dedication of 40% (winning 30%) of clean energy funds to go to low-income, communities of color, and environmental justice communities. Additionally, CSI has supported and facilitated a series of national strategy sessions with grassroots leaders and environmental advocates to address policy strategies that will build towards Energy Democracy. Transportation Equity: CSI worked in two areas: (1) identifying clear equity policy demands, including around performance measures and community indicators on transportation decision-making, developed to create greater transparency, accountability, and participatory processes at the federal, state, and local level, and (2) deep work across community and government to support transit equity campaigns and institutional practice in key localities and regions. As a member of the national Transportation for America (T4A) Coalition and as a steering committee member of the now independent Equity Caucus, CSI incorporates a racially inclusive policy lens into federal transportation policy by identifying and supporting the transit priorities and concerns of communities of color, and by connecting them to national policy discussions. CSI also supports the Caucus by convening the Data and Performance Measures policy subcommittee. Locally, CSI led several sessions in both Detroit and Seattle. Additionally, CSI convened a group of local and national advocates to discuss a framework for performance management. Food and Health Equity: CSI is working with local leaders to do an assessment of the leadership of Black farmers in the South, identifying the opportunities and challenges towards developing out racially equitable and viable food hubs that can connect families and communities to healthy and affordable foods. In New York City, CSI has convened grassroots leaders seeking to develop out a micro-food hub as a model for urban agricultural innovation and entrepreneurship that will support people of color-owned food enterprises, community agriculture, and most of all build wealth through food systems to be a solution to displacement and inequity. Nationally, CSI participates in the Good Food For All Collaborative and the Health, Environment, Agriculture and Labor (HEAL) Alliance. In addition to CSIs work on food equity, CSI expanded the program area to include health equity with a focus on First Food/breastfeeding. We also released Removing Barriers to Breastfeedingan action oriented structural race analysis of the First Food system. We also announced CSIs First Food cohort will take place before the end of 2016 as well, and led a dozen workshops and presentations relating to First Food/breastfeeding research and the structural race analysis. Leaders: CSI continued work to build 21st century leadership for racial equity across grassroots, grasstops, government and in other institutions, including philanthropy. Over the course of the year, CSI facilitated over two dozen workshops with various sectors. CSI also successfully designed and executed three full-day workshop sessions in Detroit with the Detroit Equity Action Lab, CSIs Detroit cohort. CSI worked to set the groundwork to launch a community cohort focused on energy, infrastructure and the environment in the Puget Sound region. In the Fall, CSI began work to support several Annie E. Casey Foundation grantee sites through racial equity technical assistance.Race Communications: CSI produced and released a reportour second major publication on Race CommunicationsLets Talk about Race: How Racially Explicit Messaging Can Advance Equity, and strengthened relationships with organizations through dissemination of the results. CSI has established relationships with both national and local organizations across the nation, like Arkansas Public Policy Panel, Public Works, Restaurant Opportunity Center, and Youth Jobs Coalitions. Communications: In terms of number of earned media placements, 2015 is our second highest performing year (2013 had the highest in terms of unique placements and media impressions). This performance is largely due to media work by Deepa Iyer, Simran Noor, Anthony Giancatarino, and Glenn Harris. Highlights include placements on MSNBCs Melissa Harris-Perry, The Guardian-US, Grist Magazine, The Hill, Yes! Magazine, and several local and regional newspapers across the country. We had moderate success with our digital media tools, experiencing steady growth on Facebook, Twitter, and our newsletterthough we are below average in percent increase compared to organizations like Human Rights Campaign, Jobs with Justice, and other rights-based organizations based on M+Rs 2015 benchmarks report on the non-profit industry. However, our statistics are on par with our sister organizations like Advancement Project, Movement Strategy Center, and Opportunity Agenda. Lastly, Communications made significant headway for the organizational rebrand which is occurring in 2016.Multiracial Solidarity: As the American racial landscape changes, activists, organizers, and thought leaders are engaging in dialogues and practicing solidarity across various movements. CSIs Senior Fellow Deepa Iyer has been developing thought pieces and participating in conversations around advancing racial justice and equity. Deepa convened 8 community conversations using her book, We Too Sing America: South Asian, Arab, Muslim and Sikh Immigrants Shape Our Multiracial Future (The New Press), wrote five opinion editorials in outlets, including The Guardian, The Nation, and Colorlines, and provided radio interviews for over 10 local programs on issues ranging from the post 9/11 environment to solidarity across communities of color. Deepa also participated in several Solidarity Summits convened by the Open Society Foundations (OSF), the Proteus Fund, and the Ford Foundation.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CSI does not believe its financial statements include any material, uncertain tax positions. Tax filings for periods ending December 31, 2012 and later are subject to examination by applicable taxing authorities.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 4: Description of Significant Changes to Organizational Documents
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: By-laws were updated in accordance with the NYS Nonprofit Revitalization Act

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b: Form 990 Review Process
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Management reviewed a draft of the form 990 with the audit/finance committee and provided edits to the tax preparer. After this process was performed, the form 990 was sent to the full board of directors prior to being filed with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The organization has a "board approved" conflicts of interest policy. Each board member must fill out an annual declaration stating they had no conflicts or identifying the nature of their interested party transactions.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a: Compensation Review & Approval Process - CEO, Top Management
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each year, the executive committee reviews comparable salaries based on a recognized study and reviews the performance of the President to determine if the existing salary falls within these ranges. After a deliberation of this matter, a new proposed salary and benefit package is voted on.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19: Other Organization Documents Publicly Available
